options: It is usually caused by caseation of tuberculous lymphadenitis.
The abscess may have two components (collar-stud abscess).
The condition is mildly painful with low-grade fever.
Anti-tuberculous treatment is an essential part of treatment.
Drainage is best achieved by a wide incision.
questions.explanation:
A cold abscess should be treated with systemic anti-tuberculous medication and aspiration, if necessary
. Wide incision and drainage are generally avoided because they can lead to the formation of a chronic discharging sinus that is difficult to heal.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding branchial cysts and fistulae, all are true, EXCEPT:
options: A branchial cyst is observed in the neonate.
A branchial fistula is present at birth.
A branchial cyst is partially covered by the sternomastoid muscle.
The main differential diagnosis of a branchial cyst is a cold abscess.
A branchial cyst contains cholesterol crystals on aspiration.
questions.explanation:
A branchial fistula is a congenital tract that is present from birth, often noted as a small discharging pit in the neck
. A branchial cyst, however, is a closed remnant that typically presents later in life (usually in late childhood or early adulthood) when it enlarges due to fluid accumulation or infection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding thoracic outlet syndrome, all statements are true, EXCEPT:
options: In all cases a cervical rib is present.
The commonest manifestations are caused by compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus.
There may be hyposthesia of the medial side of the forearm.
It is one cause of Raynaud's phenomenon.
There may be chronic heaviness and oedema of the upper limb.
questions.explanation:
While a cervical rib is a classic cause of thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), it is present in only a minority of cases
. More often, TOS is caused by compression from soft tissue structures, such as fibrous bands, abnormal scalene muscle insertions, or post-traumatic changes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding tracheostomy, all the following statements are true, EXCEPT:
options: Tracheostomy is indicated if mechanical ventilation is needed for a long time.
Emergency tracheostomy is done at the scene of an accident if there is upper airway obstruction.
Percutaneous tracheostomy is suitable for critically-ill ICU patients.
In adults, an opening is made between the 2nd and 3rd tracheal rings.
One of its possible complications is subglottic stenosis.
questions.explanation:
In an emergency field setting with upper airway obstruction, the procedure of choice is a cricothyroidotomy
. It is a faster, simpler, and safer procedure to establish an emergency airway compared to a tracheostomy, which is a formal surgical procedure best performed in a controlled operating room or ICU setting.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A midline cystic swelling in the neck moves up and down with deglutition and with protrusion of the tongue
. This describes a:
questions.explanation:
A thyroglossal duct cyst is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct, the path the thyroid gland follows during its descent from the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue
. Because the duct is attached to the base of the tongue, the cyst characteristically elevates when the tongue is protruded, as well as with swallowing.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site for lip cancer is the:
options: Lower lip at the junction of the middle and outer thirds.
Upper lip at the junction of middle and outer thirds.
questions.explanation:
Over 90% of lip cancers are squamous cell carcinomas that occur on the lower lip
. This is primarily due to higher cumulative sun (UV radiation) exposure compared to the more shaded upper lip.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The anterior two-thirds of the tongue receives general sensation (touch, pain, temperature) through the:
options: Chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.
questions.explanation:
General sensation for the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is supplied by the lingual nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3)
. Taste sensation for this area is carried by the chorda tympani (a branch of the facial nerve) which travels with the lingual nerve.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following is true about ameloblastoma (previously called adamantinoma) EXCEPT:
options: It is usually located near the symphysis menti.
It originates from remnants of the dental lamina (cells of Mallasez).
It grows in the body and ramus of the mandible.
It has a multiloculated 'soap bubble' appearance on X-ray.
questions.explanation:
Ameloblastoma is a benign but locally aggressive odontogenic tumor that most commonly occurs in the posterior mandible, specifically the molar-ramus area
. It is much less common in the anterior mandible near the symphysis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Salivary gland stones are most common in which glands?
questions.explanation:
Over 80% of sialoliths (salivary stones) occur in the submandibular gland
. This is attributed to the long, upward, and tortuous course of its duct (Wharton's duct) and the viscous, alkaline, calcium-rich saliva it produces.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following is correct about salivary glands’ stones except:
options: Neck ultrasound may be a useful investigation.
In bimanual examination, they are better felt from inside the mouth.
Pain may refer to the tongue or teeth.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following are true about salivary gland tumors EXCEPT:
options: 80% of them occur in the parotid gland.
80% of parotid gland tumors are benign.
80% of parotid gland tumors occur in the deep lobe.
80% of benign parotid tumors are pleomorphic adenomas.
questions.explanation:
Approximately 80% of all parotid gland tumors arise in the much larger superficial lobe, which lies lateral to the facial nerve
. Deep lobe tumors account for only about 20% and can present as a parapharyngeal mass.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 24-year-old female presents with a neck swelling on the left side, located in the carotid triangle deep to the sternomastoid
. It is mobile side to side and transilluminates
. Aspiration reveals mucoid fluid rich in cholesterol crystals
. Your provisional diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
This is a classic description of a second branchial cleft cyst
. The location at the anterior border of the sternomastoid muscle, its cystic nature, and especially the aspiration finding of cholesterol crystals are pathognomonic.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 43-year-old teacher underwent left parotidectomy
. Upon awakening from surgery, paralysis of the left lower lip was observed
. This complication was most likely due to injury to which structure?
questions.explanation:
The original file states 'Cervical branch', however, weakness of the depressor muscles of the lower lip is classically caused by injury to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve, not the cervical branch (which supplies the platysma)
. Given the options, the cervical branch is the closest distractor, as platysma contributes to lip depression, but marginal mandibular is the precise answer.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 9-year-old boy has a translucent swelling on the left side of his neck in the supraclavicular region, diagnosed as a cystic hygroma
. What is true of this condition?
options: It arises from sweat glands in the neck.
It is usually an anterior midline structure.
It may extend into the mediastinum.
Its lesions are usually easy to enucleate.
questions.explanation:
Cystic hygromas (lymphangiomas) are congenital malformations of the lymphatic system
. When they arise in the posterior triangle or supraclavicular fossa, they can extend inferiorly through the thoracic inlet into the superior mediastinum, which can cause respiratory compromise.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 62-year-old man undergoes excision of a tumor of the submandibular gland
. He is most likely to have an injury to which of the following nerves?
options: Maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve
Frontozygomatic branch of the facial nerve
questions.explanation:
During submandibular gland excision, three nerves are at particular risk: the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve (supplies lower lip depressors), the hypoglossal nerve (motor to tongue), and the lingual nerve (sensation to tongue)
. Of these, the lingual nerve is particularly vulnerable as it loops under the submandibular duct
. The answer provided in the text is 'Lingual nerve', which is a correct and plausible risk.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 62-year-old alcoholic presents with a 1
.5 cm squamous cell carcinoma on the left lateral aspect of her tongue, not fixed to the jaw
. There are no palpable neck nodes
. What is the most appropriate management?
options: Wide excision and left radical neck dissection
Wide excision of ulcer and radiotherapy
questions.explanation:
The standard of care for a small (T1/T2) oral tongue cancer is wide local excision of the primary tumor with an adequate margin
. Given the high rate of occult (non-palpable) nodal metastases from tongue cancer, treatment of the neck (either elective neck dissection or radiotherapy) is also required, making 'Wide excision and left radical neck dissection' the most comprehensive treatment plan listed.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 59-year-old woman has a carcinoma confirmed on biopsy in the posterior third of her tongue
. What is true in this situation?
options: Lymph gland spread is often encountered.
The recurrent laryngeal nerve is infiltrated.
questions.explanation:
Cancers of the posterior one-third (base) of the tongue have a much richer lymphatic drainage than the anterior tongue
. Consequently, they have a very high incidence of early lymphatic spread to the cervical lymph nodes, often bilaterally
. This contributes to their overall poorer prognosis compared to anterior tongue cancers.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Adenocarcinoma is the predominant malignant lesion in which of the following sites?
questions.explanation:
The hard palate is rich in minor salivary glands
. Tumors arising in these glands are the most common malignancies of the hard palate, with adenoid cystic carcinoma and adenocarcinoma being the most frequent types
. The other sites listed are predominantly affected by squamous cell carcinoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 58-year-old woman undergoes excision biopsy of a tumor in the left posterior triangle of her neck, which histology confirms as metastatic cancer
. What is the most likely site of the primary tumor?
questions.explanation:
The posterior triangle nodes drain the nasopharynx, oropharynx, and hypopharynx
. A metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in this location in an adult strongly suggests a primary tumor in one of these areas
. The piriform fossa (part of the hypopharynx) is a very common site for an occult primary tumor to present with neck metastasis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The classic complete radical neck dissection for palpable adenopathy includes removal of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
A classic radical neck dissection involves the en bloc removal of all lymph node-bearing tissue from Level I to V
. This traditionally includes the sacrifice and removal of three non-lymphatic structures: the sternocleidomastoid muscle, the internal jugular vein, and the spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 40-year-old woman is suspected of having a carotid body tumor
. Which one of the following is most characteristic of such a tumor?
options: They are more common at sea level.
They arise from structures that respond to changes in blood volume.
They arise from structures that respond to changes in PO2.
questions.explanation:
The carotid body is a chemoreceptor located at the carotid bifurcation that responds to changes in the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and pH in the blood
. A carotid body tumor (paraganglioma) arises from the chief cells of this structure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
Following surgical resection of a large thyroid mass, a patient complains of persistent hoarseness and a weak voice
. What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
options: Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve
Injury to the superior laryngeal nerve
Scar tissue extending to the vocal cords
questions.explanation:
The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid
. Unilateral injury to this nerve during thyroid surgery paralyzes the ipsilateral vocal cord, leading to a hoarse, breathy voice.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is the most common site for foreign bodies in the head and neck in children?
questions.explanation:
The external auditory canal of the ear is a very common location for children to place foreign bodies such as beads, food particles, or small toy parts
. This often presents with pain, discharge, or hearing loss.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 33-year-old female noted a discharge from a sinus below the right angle of the mandible
. She recalls previous episodes of fullness and mild pain in this region
. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
This history is classic for an infected second branchial cleft cyst that has ruptured externally, forming a sinus tract
. The location at the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and a history of a preceding cystic swelling are key features.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A 5-year-old girl presents with difficulty breathing
. On examination, a 3-cm mass is found in the midline on the posterior aspect of the tongue
. The most likely diagnosis is:
options: Foreign body stuck to the tongue
questions.explanation:
A lingual thyroid is ectopic thyroid tissue located at the base of the tongue, resulting from a failure of the thyroid gland to descend during embryological development
. It presents as a midline mass at the foramen cecum and can enlarge, causing symptoms of airway obstruction or dysphagia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Acute bacterial sialadenitis most commonly affects the:
questions.explanation:
Acute bacterial sialadenitis, or parotitis, most commonly affects the parotid gland
. It typically occurs in elderly, dehydrated, or post-operative patients when decreased salivary flow allows bacteria from the oral cavity (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus) to ascend Stensen's duct.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What percentage of salivary stones occur in the submandibular gland?
questions.explanation:
The overwhelming majority (80-90%) of salivary gland stones form in the submandibular gland
. This is due to its long, upward-sloping duct (Wharton's duct) and the viscous, calcium-rich nature of its saliva.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common salivary tumor is:
questions.explanation:
Pleomorphic adenoma (benign mixed tumor) is the most common neoplasm of the salivary glands, accounting for about two-thirds of all parotid tumors
. It typically presents as a slow-growing, painless, firm mass.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements about salivary gland neoplasms is correct?
options: 75% of salivary neoplasms arise in the parotid gland.
80% of benign parotid tumours are pleomorphic adenomas.
questions.explanation: These are the well-known 'rules of 80' for parotid tumors: about 80% of salivary gland tumors are in the parotid, about 80% of parotid tumors are benign, and about 80% of benign parotid tumors are pleomorphic adenomas.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Warthin's tumor refers to:
questions.explanation:
Adenolymphoma is the formal name for Warthin's tumor
. It is the second most common benign parotid tumor, characterized by a unique histology of cystic spaces with papillary projections lined by oncocytic epithelium, all set within a dense lymphoid stroma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A malignant parotid tumour is characterized by:
questions.explanation:
While benign tumors are typically painless, slow-growing, and mobile, features suggestive of malignancy include rapid growth, pain, fixation to the skin or deep structures, and invasion of the facial nerve causing facial weakness or paralysis
. Any of these signs should raise a high suspicion for cancer.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which salivary carcinoma has a particularly poor prognosis?
questions.explanation:
High-grade salivary gland carcinomas, including high-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and adenocarcinoma, generally have a poor prognosis
. Squamous cell carcinoma, in particular, is aggressive with early regional and distant metastasis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which salivary carcinoma is known for its tendency for perineural spread, potentially to the brain?
questions.explanation:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a strong predilection for perineural invasion
. This allows the tumor to track along nerve sheaths far from the primary site, leading to a high rate of local recurrence and late distant metastases
. It can spread intracranially by tracking along nerves like the facial or trigeminal nerve.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Adenolymphomas (Warthin's tumors) are almost exclusively found in the:
questions.explanation:
Warthin's tumor occurs almost exclusively in the parotid gland, particularly in the tail of the gland
. It is strongly associated with smoking and is more common in older men
. It can also be bilateral or multifocal within the same gland.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common indication for removal of a sublingual salivary gland is:
questions.explanation:
A ranula is a mucus retention cyst or extravasation pseudocyst arising from the sublingual gland
. The definitive treatment for a ranula, especially a recurrent or plunging ranula, is the surgical excision of the offending sublingual gland to prevent recurrence.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The Parotid (Stensen's) duct opens into the mouth opposite the:
options: Near to midline of hard palate
questions.explanation: The parotid duct, also known as Stensen's duct, crosses the masseter muscle, pierces the buccinator muscle, and opens into the oral cavity on the buccal mucosa, opposite the crown of the upper second molar tooth.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The treatment for a submandibular calculus located within the distal duct that is palpable in the floor of the mouth is to:
options: Remove the stone by making an incision directly over it in the floor of the mouth.
Slit open the duct at the papilla
questions.explanation:
For stones that are located in the distal portion of Wharton's duct and are palpable intraorally, the simplest and preferred treatment is an intraoral sialolithotomy
. A small incision is made in the floor of the mouth directly over the stone, allowing it to be removed while preserving the gland.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A pharyngeal pouch (Zenker's diverticulum) should be suspected in the presence of:
questions.explanation:
A Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch that forms in the hypopharynx
. Food becomes trapped in the pouch, leading to symptoms of dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of old food particles, gurgling in the neck, chronic cough, and aspiration pneumonia from overflowing contents.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the pharyngeal pouch (Zenker's diverticulum), which statement is incorrect?
options: It usually deviates to the left side of the neck.
It may be visible as a swelling in the neck.
It is twice as common in males as in females.
questions.explanation:
While Zenker's diverticulum is more common in males, the male-to-female ratio is not as high as 2:1
. The accepted ratio is closer to 1
.5:1
. All other statements are correct characteristics of a Zenker's diverticulum.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A branchial cyst commonly arises from a remnant of the:
questions.explanation:
The vast majority (over 95%) of branchial cysts and fistulae arise from a persistent remnant of the second branchial cleft
. This accounts for their typical location along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding branchial cysts, which statement is incorrect?
options: It arises from the second branchial cleft.
It usually appears between the ages of 20-25 years.
It protrudes from beneath the anterior border of the sternomastoid muscle.
It is usually lined by squamous epithelium.
questions.explanation:
All the statements provided are classic features of a second branchial cleft cyst
. It arises from the second cleft, typically presents in early adulthood, is found at the anterior SCM border, and is lined by squamous or columnar epithelium with underlying lymphoid tissue
. Therefore, the incorrect option is that there is an incorrect statement.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A branchial cyst is best differentiated from a cold abscess by:
questions.explanation:
While both can be cystic and may have similar locations, the definitive diagnostic feature on aspiration is the contents
. A branchial cyst classically yields a thin, straw-colored or mucoid fluid that contains cholesterol crystals, which gives it a shimmering appearance
. A cold abscess contains caseous necrotic material, and a pyogenic abscess contains pus.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Characteristics of cystic hygroma include all EXCEPT:
options: It develops from sequestered jugular lymph sacs.
It characteristically occupies the middle third of the neck.
It can enlarge with crying or a URI.
questions.explanation:
Cystic hygroma (lymphangioma) most commonly occurs in the posterior triangle of the neck (lower third) or the supraclavicular fossa
. Its classic location is not the middle third of the anterior neck.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement is inappropriate for a cystic hygroma?
options: It is a type of cavernous hemangioma.
It can be one of the earliest swellings of the neck to appear in life.
A large one can obstruct labour (dystocia).
questions.explanation:
A cystic hygroma is a lymphangioma, which is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic vessels
. A cavernous hemangioma is a malformation of blood vessels (veins)
. They are distinct pathological entities, although both are types of vascular malformations.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Treatment of Ludwig's angina includes:
options: Surgical decompression of the submandibular and sublingual spaces
Securing the airway, potentially with tracheostomy
questions.explanation:
The management of Ludwig's angina is a multi-pronged emergency approach
. It requires (1) immediate securing of the airway, which is at risk from laryngeal edema, (2) high-dose intravenous antibiotics covering oral flora, and (3) surgical incision and drainage to decompress the fascial spaces.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A ranula is a:
options: Cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth
questions.explanation:
A ranula is a specific type of mucocele (mucus-filled cyst) found on the floor of the mouth, arising from the sublingual gland
. It presents as a bluish, translucent, dome-shaped swelling to one side of the frenulum.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The 'potato tumour' of the neck refers to a:
questions.explanation:
The potato tumour of the neck is a synonym for a carotid body tumour (or chemodectoma), which is a rare, usually benign, and highly vascular neoplasm arising from the paraganglionic cells at the carotid artery bifurcation
.It is characterized as a firm, slow-growing nodular mass that is mobile horizontally but not vertically, often exhibiting transmitted pulsation
. Key Characteristics and Clinical Features:Appearance: Named for its resemblance to a potato
.Location: Located at the carotid bifurcation, causing splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries
.Symptoms: Often presents as a painless mass, but may cause hoarseness, dysphagia, tongue numbness, or fainting (due to carotid sinus pressure)
.Behavior: Typically benign, but can be locally invasive
. Diagnosis and Treatment:Diagnosis: Primarily diagnosed using imaging such as Doppler ultrasound, CT, MRI, or carotid angiography
.Treatment: Surgical resection is the standard treatment, though these tumors are often slow-growing
.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A laryngocele is common in:
questions.explanation:
A laryngocele is an abnormal air-filled sac that is a dilatation of the laryngeal saccule
. It is caused by a sustained increase in intralaryngeal pressure, such as that produced by glass blowers, musicians who play wind instruments, and people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and cough.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Tuberculous cervical lymphadenitis (scrofula) most commonly affects the:
questions.explanation: Tuberculous infection of the cervical lymph nodes most commonly involves the upper deep cervical chain (jugulodigastric nodes) and the nodes in the posterior triangle, often forming a matted chain along the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Of the approximately 800 lymph nodes in the body, the number of lymph nodes in the neck is around:
questions.explanation:
The head and neck region has a remarkably high concentration of lymph nodes
. It is estimated that approximately 300 lymph nodes, or nearly 40% of the body's total, are located in the head and neck.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A cervical rib may present with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
A cervical rib can cause thoracic outlet syndrome by compressing the brachial plexus (causing neurological symptoms like pain and numbness), the subclavian artery (causing ischemic symptoms or a bruit from stenosis), or the subclavian vein
. The rib itself may also be palpable as a hard lump in the supraclavicular fossa.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Pain in the arm due to a cervical rib is primarily caused by:
options: Compression of the T1 nerve root
Compression of the C7 nerve root
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In a radical neck dissection, all the following are removed EXCEPT the:
questions.explanation:
The carotid artery (common, internal, and external) and the vagus nerve are vital structures that are carefully preserved during a neck dissection
. A classic radical neck dissection involves removal of the internal jugular vein, sternocleidomastoid muscle, and spinal accessory nerve along with all the lymphatic tissue.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A cystic hygroma is a type of:
questions.explanation:
Cystic hygroma is the most common form of lymphangioma, which is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic vessels
. It presents as a large, multiloculated, fluid-filled cystic mass.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following neck swellings is brilliantly translucent on transillumination?
questions.explanation:
Cystic hygromas are filled with clear lymph fluid and have very thin walls
. This allows them to transilluminate brilliantly, a key diagnostic clinical sign
. Dermoid and sebaceous cysts are filled with keratin and sebum, which are opaque, while branchial cysts contain turbid fluid with cholesterol and do not transilluminate well.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is wrong about Hodgkin lymphoma?
options: It generally has a better prognosis than Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL).
Histologically, there are few malignant cells outnumbered by inflammatory cells.
It is characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells.
questions.explanation:
Staging laparotomy was historically used to stage Hodgkin lymphoma but has been completely replaced by modern imaging techniques like CT and PET scans
. It is no longer considered an essential or routine part of the diagnostic workup.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site of initial lymph node enlargement in Hodgkin lymphoma is:
questions.explanation:
Hodgkin lymphoma most commonly presents with painless enlargement of lymph nodes above the diaphragm
. The cervical lymph nodes (specifically the lower cervical and supraclavicular nodes) are the most frequent initial site of presentation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common presentation of Hodgkin lymphoma is:
questions.explanation: The hallmark and most common presenting sign of Hodgkin lymphoma is the development of a non-tender, rubbery, enlarged lymph node, most often in the cervical or supraclavicular region.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Systemic 'B' symptoms of Hodgkin lymphoma include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
The classic 'B symptoms' in lymphoma staging, which have prognostic significance, are: unexplained fever, drenching night sweats, and significant unexplained weight loss
. Pruritus is a common symptom but is not classified as a B symptom
. Headache is not a characteristic symptom.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All are true regarding ameloblastoma EXCEPT:
options: X-ray shows a 'honeycomb' or 'soap bubble' appearance.
Pathologically it can mimic basal cell carcinoma.
It is more common in females.
It can cross the symphysis menti.
questions.explanation:
Ameloblastoma has a roughly equal incidence in males and females; it does not show a strong predilection for females
. The provided answer key gives 'd
. can cross the symphysis menti'
. While ameloblastomas respect the midline symphysis, very large and aggressive lesions can eventually cross it, so stating it cannot is not definitively true.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All are true regarding giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma) of the jaw EXCEPT:
options: Pathologically it is a giant cell tumor.
questions.explanation:
Giant cell tumors of the bone classically occur after skeletal maturity, typically in patients between 20 and 40 years old
. They are uncommon in skeletally immature children
. 'Chocolate-like fluid' refers to a bone cyst.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All are true regarding a dentigerous cyst EXCEPT:
options: It is a type of odontogenic cyst.
It contains an unerupted tooth inside.
Treatment is removal of the cyst lining and tooth.
It affects the maxilla more than the mandible.
questions.explanation:
Dentigerous cysts are more common in the mandible than the maxilla
. The most common location is surrounding the crown of an unerupted mandibular third molar.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding fissural cysts of the mandible:
options: Nasopalatine duct cyst is an example.
It is acquired by staphylococcal infection.
Treatment requires removal of the entire wall.
They occur in embryonic fusion lines of the face.
questions.explanation:
Fissural (or non-odontogenic) cysts arise from epithelial remnants trapped during the embryonic fusion of facial processes
. They are developmental in origin, not acquired from a bacterial infection
. The nasopalatine duct cyst is the most common example.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a predisposing factor for a hernia?
questions.explanation:
Any condition that chronically raises intra-abdominal pressure can predispose to hernia formation
. This includes COPD (coughing), obesity, pregnancy, and ascites
. Urinary stones cause acute pain but do not cause a chronic increase in intra-abdominal pressure and are not a recognized risk factor for hernias.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following hernias is more common in multiparous women?
questions.explanation:
Pregnancy causes stretching of the abdominal wall and linea alba, which can lead to widening of the umbilical ring
. As a result, umbilical and paraumbilical hernias are more common in multiparous women.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a complication of an inguinal hernia?
questions.explanation:
While bowel within a hernia can become ischemic and bleed, spontaneous bleeding is not a recognized primary complication of an uncomplicated hernia itself
. The main complications are incarceration (irreducibility), obstruction (blockage of the bowel lumen), and strangulation (compromise of the blood supply).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true in relation to strangulated hernias?
options: They present with local pain and then signs of bowel obstruction.
A previously reducible hernia can strangulate at any time.
Strangulation is more common in femoral hernias.
Strangulation can be reliably excluded in irreducible hernias on clinical examination.
questions.explanation:
It is not possible to reliably exclude strangulation in an incarcerated (irreducible) hernia based on clinical examination alone
. While tenderness, erythema, and toxicity suggest strangulation, their absence does not rule it out
. Any acute, painful, irreducible hernia must be assumed to be strangulated and requires emergency surgery.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the anatomy of the inguinal canal, which of the following is true?
options: In infants the internal and external rings are almost superimposed.
The inferior epigastric vessels lie posterior and lateral to the internal ring.
The inguinal canal is about 10 cm long.
The internal ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis.
questions.explanation:
In infants, the inguinal canal is shorter and straighter than in adults, with the internal (deep) and external (superficial) rings located nearly on top of one another
. As the child grows, the abdominal wall develops, and the rings separate, creating a more oblique canal.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is true about a sliding inguinal hernia?
options: It should be suspected in small hernias.
It is more common in young patients.
It is impossible to control with a truss, and hence an operation is indicated.
questions.explanation:
The original key shows 'd'
. This is the best description among the options
. A sliding hernia involves a retroperitoneal organ (like the bladder or colon) forming part of the hernia sac wall
. These are typically large, broad-necked hernias that are difficult or impossible to control effectively with a truss, making surgery the indicated treatment.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding a femoral hernia is true?
options: The femoral canal occupies the most lateral compartment of the femoral sheath.
It can be easily controlled by a truss.
Strangulation is the initial presentation in 40 per cent of patients.
An operation is only occasionally required.
questions.explanation:
Femoral hernias have a narrow, rigid neck (the femoral ring), making them highly prone to incarceration and strangulation
. It is estimated that up to 40% of femoral hernias present as an emergency with obstruction or strangulation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding umbilical hernias?
options: Men are affected more frequently than women.
Irreducibility is common due to omental adhesions within the sac.
The Mayo operation involves a mesh repair of the hernia.
Infantile umbilical hernias need immediate surgery.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following are true regarding ‘burst abdomens’ (fascial dehiscence)?
options: The incidence is around 10–15 per cent.
Midline and vertical incisions are more likely to burst than transverse incisions.
Catgut suture is associated with a lower risk of burst abdomen.
questions.explanation:
Midline vertical incisions cut across the lines of tension in the abdominal wall aponeurosis
. They are under more constant tension than transverse incisions, which run parallel to these lines, and therefore have a higher risk of fascial dehiscence.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In incompletely descended testes, which of the following statements is FALSE?
options: The incidence in full-term male infants is about 4 per cent.
A testis absent from the scrotum after 3 months is unlikely to descend.
An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches.
Orchidopexy reduces the chances of developing a testicular tumour.
questions.explanation:
While orchidopexy (surgically bringing the testis into the scrotum) improves fertility potential and allows for easier examination of the testis, it does not eliminate the inherently increased risk of malignancy associated with an undescended testis
. The risk remains higher than in a normal testis, although placing it in the scrotum facilitates early detection of any tumor.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements are true about a hydrocele except:
options: A hydrocele is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis.
A congenital hydrocele causes an intermittent swelling.
An acute hydrocele in a young man may be a sinister finding.
Testicular pathology may cause a secondary hydrocele.
Simple needle drainage is an effective permanent treatment.
questions.explanation:
Simple needle aspiration of a hydrocele provides temporary relief, but the fluid reaccumulates rapidly because the underlying fluid-secreting tunica vaginalis is left intact
. Definitive surgical treatment requires excision or eversion of the hydrocele sac (tunica vaginalis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In testicular tumours, which of the following statements is FALSE?
options: A scrotal lump that is inseparable from the testis is likely to be a tumour.
Lymphatic spread is usually to the inguinal lymph nodes.
Teratomas occur in the third decade and seminomas in the fourth decade.
Seminomas usually spread via the lymphatics.
questions.explanation:
The lymphatic drainage of the testis follows its embryological descent from the abdomen
. Therefore, it drains to the retroperitoneal (paraaortic) lymph nodes
. The inguinal nodes drain the skin of the scrotum, not the testis itself.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following are true about the inguinal canal EXCEPT:
options: It is a 4 cm tunnel in the lower abdominal muscles.
It contains the spermatic cord in males & round ligament in females.
The floor is formed by the inguinal ligament & the roof is formed by the conjoint tendon.
Boundaries include the external oblique muscle posteriorly & fascia transversalis anteriorly.
questions.explanation:
The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is formed by the external oblique aponeurosis
. The posterior wall is formed by the fascia transversalis
. This statement has the anatomy reversed.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following organs can be found within a hernia sac EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
The prostate is a fixed, retroperitoneal organ located deep within the pelvis
. It is not mobile and cannot enter a hernia sac
. The other organs listed (colon, ovary, bladder) are intraperitoneal or partially retroperitoneal and can be found in hernia sacs.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common type of hernia is:
questions.explanation:
Inguinal hernias (both direct and indirect) are the most common type of abdominal wall hernia, accounting for approximately 75% of all cases
. They are particularly common in men.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following are causes of acquired hernia EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
An unobliterated or patent processus vaginalis is the cause of a congenital indirect inguinal hernia
. Acquired hernias develop due to factors that weaken the abdominal wall or chronically increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, obesity, or pregnancy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A Richter's hernia is a type of hernia containing:
options: Two loops of bowel in the sac.
Only a portion of the circumference of the intestine in the sac.
A portion of the Urinary Bladder in the sac.
questions.explanation:
A Richter's hernia is one in which only a part of the intestinal wall's circumference becomes trapped in the hernia defect
. It is dangerous because it can strangulate and become necrotic without causing a full bowel obstruction, leading to a delayed diagnosis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All the following are true when the sac content is omentum EXCEPT:
options: It gives no gurgling sensation on reduction.
Reduction begins with difficulty but finishes easily.
questions.explanation:
Omentum within a hernia sac tends to form adhesions and is often difficult to reduce
. Bowel, on the other hand, is classically described as 'reducing with a gurgle', and often the reduction is easy once it begins
. The phrase in D describes the reduction of bowel, not omentum.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the superficial (external) inguinal ring, all are true EXCEPT:
options: It is located superior and medial to the pubic tubercle.
It is also named the 'superficial ring'.
It is a slit-like opening in the external oblique aponeurosis.
The hernia sac of a direct hernia does not pass through it.
questions.explanation:
The original file states '1/2 inch above Mid inguinal point'
. This is the surface marking for the deep (internal) inguinal ring
. The superficial (external) ring is located just superior and medial to the pubic tubercle
. A large direct or indirect hernia will protrude through the superficial ring to become a visible groin swelling
. So D is also incorrect.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Injury to the ilioinguinal nerve during hernia repair can cause:
options: Direct hernia due to paralysis of the conjoint tendon.
Numbness of the scrotum & medial aspect of the upper thigh.
questions.explanation:
The ilioinguinal nerve provides sensation to the skin of the upper medial thigh, the root of the penis, and the upper part of the scrotum in males (or labia majora in females)
. Injury to this nerve during inguinal hernia surgery is a common cause of chronic groin pain and numbness in these areas.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The boundaries of Hesselbach's triangle are:
options: Inferior epigastric artery medially & conjoint tendon laterally.
Lateral border of rectus muscle medially, inferior epigastric artery laterally, and inguinal ligament inferiorly.
Ilioinguinal nerve laterally & inguinal ligament medially.
questions.explanation:
Hesselbach's triangle is the site where direct inguinal hernias occur
. Its boundaries are: Medially: the lateral border of the rectus abdominis muscle
. Laterally: the inferior epigastric vessels
. Inferiorly: the inguinal ligament.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An indirect (oblique) inguinal hernia:
options: Is directed straight forward through the abdominal wall.
Can occur at any age & is bilateral in about 10-15% of cases.
questions.explanation:
Indirect inguinal hernias are congenital in origin (due to a patent processus vaginalis) and can therefore present at any age, from infancy to old age
. They are the most common type of hernia in both sexes and at all ages
. They have a known predisposition to be bilateral.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following is true about the clinical picture of an indirect inguinal hernia EXCEPT:
options: The swelling increases in size with coughing.
It gives a gurgling sensation during reduction if it contains bowel.
The direction of reduction is straight backward.
questions.explanation:
An indirect hernia follows the oblique path of the inguinal canal
. To reduce it, one must apply pressure upwards, outwards, and backwards, along the line of the canal towards the deep inguinal ring
. A direct hernia, in contrast, reduces straight backward.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About the deep ring occlusion test, all are true EXCEPT:
options: It can differentiate between indirect, direct, & femoral hernias.
It is not commonly performed now.
In this test, an indirect hernia does not come out until the thumb is released.
The test starts by asking the patient to reduce the hernia.
questions.explanation:
The deep ring occlusion test can help differentiate an indirect hernia from a direct hernia
. However, it cannot differentiate a femoral hernia, which emerges inferior to the inguinal ligament.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: During surgery, a hernia sac can be identified by all of the following EXCEPT:
options: It has a pearly white color.
It contains the vas deferens & spermatic artery.
questions.explanation:
The hernia sac is formed from peritoneum
. The vas deferens and spermatic vessels are structures of the spermatic cord
. In an indirect hernia, the sac lies within the spermatic cord, alongside these structures, but does not contain them within its wall.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Herniorrhaphy (tissue repair) has the following characters EXCEPT:
options: Repair of the hernia by suturing tissue layers together.
Should not be performed under tension.
It is indicated for small hernias in young patients with good muscles.
Bassini repair is one of its techniques.
questions.explanation:
Absorbable sutures are not suitable for a durable hernia repair as they would dissolve before adequate scar tissue has formed, leading to a high rate of recurrence
. Hernia repairs are performed with permanent, non-absorbable sutures or mesh.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding a direct hernia, all the following are true EXCEPT:
options: The neck of the sac is medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
The sac and its contents are contained within the spermatic cord.
It usually occurs in the elderly and more than 50% are bilateral.
It is uncommonly complicated by strangulation.
questions.explanation:
A direct hernia pushes directly through the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal (Hesselbach's triangle)
. It is separate from the spermatic cord
. In contrast, an indirect hernia's sac enters the deep ring and travels within the layers of the spermatic cord.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Any of the following can be a complication of a hernia EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
While severe trauma could theoretically cause a hernia to rupture, it is an extremely rare event
. Bleeding into the sac or from strangulated bowel is more common
. The main complications are irreducibility, obstruction, and strangulation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An irreducible (incarcerated) but not strangulated hernia can be presented by any of the following EXCEPT:
options: There are no signs of intestinal obstruction.
questions.explanation:
A simple irreducible hernia still has a patent connection to the abdominal cavity
. Therefore, when intra-abdominal pressure is raised by coughing, that pressure is transmitted into the sac, creating a visible or palpable cough impulse
. Loss of the cough impulse is a sign that the neck of the sac has become blocked by edema and swelling, and is a worrying sign of impending or actual strangulation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A strangulated hernia can be presented by:
options: Lost expansile cough impulse, tenderness, tension, & irreducibility.
Tenderness with an intact impulse on cough.
questions.explanation:
Strangulation is a clinical diagnosis based on a constellation of signs
. The hernia becomes painful, tender, and tense due to edema
. It is irreducible, and as the neck becomes obstructed, the cough impulse is lost
. The patient will also develop signs of intestinal obstruction.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which type of hernia is most liable for strangulation?
questions.explanation:
Femoral hernias have the highest rate of strangulation because they pass through a narrow and rigid anatomical space, the femoral ring
. Direct inguinal hernias, with their wide necks, have the lowest rate.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common type of hernia that presents as a strangulated emergency is:
questions.explanation:
While femoral hernias have the highest *rate* of strangulation, inguinal hernias are vastly more common overall
. Therefore, in absolute numbers, the most frequently encountered strangulated hernia in the emergency room is a strangulated inguinal hernia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The pathological sequence of a strangulated hernia includes all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
The primary pathology is vascular compromise
. Constriction at the hernia neck first obstructs low-pressure venous return, causing congestion and edema
. This swelling then worsens the constriction, eventually impeding high-pressure arterial inflow, leading to ischemia and gangrene
. Intestinal obstruction is a parallel process but not the cause of the gangrene.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: During hernial repair surgery, all the following are 'wrong' principles except:
options: Viable intestine is returned back to the abdomen.
Necrotic omentum should never to be excised.
A mesh should be applied to tightly cover the cord.
Herniorrhaphy (tissue repair) should be performed under tension.
questions.explanation:
A fundamental principle of strangulated hernia surgery is to assess the viability of the contents
. If the intestine is deemed viable after being released and warmed, it is safely returned to the abdominal cavity
. Non-viable bowel must be resected
. All other statements describe incorrect surgical principles.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The loss of an expansile impulse on coughing during hernia examination is a key sign of:
questions.explanation:
Loss of the cough impulse implies that the neck of the hernia sac is completely occluded, preventing the transmission of intra-abdominal pressure
. This is a critical sign that distinguishes a simple incarcerated hernia from a strangulated hernia, where vascular compromise is occurring.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The synthetic material most commonly used for tension-free hernioplasty is:
questions.explanation:
Polypropylene is a permanent, non-absorbable synthetic polymer that is macroporous, promoting tissue ingrowth and forming a strong scar plate
. It is the most widely used material for mesh hernia repairs (e.g., the Lichtenstein repair)
. Vicryl is absorbable and unsuitable for this purpose.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is not a predisposing factor for a hernia?
questions.explanation:
Hernias are caused by chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure
. COPD (cough), obesity, pregnancy, and peritoneal dialysis all cause this
. Urinary stones cause acute pain and potential obstruction but are not a cause of chronically elevated intra-abdominal pressure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following hernias is more common in multiparous women?
questions.explanation:
Multiple pregnancies stretch the linea alba and the fascia around the umbilicus, weakening these structures
. This makes multiparous women more susceptible to developing umbilical and paraumbilical hernias.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is not a complication of an inguinal hernia?
questions.explanation:
Bleeding is not a primary complication of an inguinal hernia itself
. The classic complications are incarceration (the hernia cannot be reduced), obstruction (the lumen of the bowel within the sac is blocked), and strangulation (the blood supply to the hernia contents is compromised).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true in relation to strangulated hernias?
options: They present with local and then generalized abdominal pain and vomiting.
A reducible hernia can strangulate at any time.
This is more common in femoral hernia.
They can be reliably excluded in irreducible hernias on clinical examination.
questions.explanation:
The clinical distinction between an irreducible (incarcerated) hernia and a strangulated one can be impossible
. While signs like tenderness, fever, or skin changes suggest strangulation, their absence does not rule it out
. Any acutely painful, irreducible hernia must be treated as a surgical emergency.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the anatomy of the inguinal canal, which of the following are true?
options: In infants the internal and external rings are almost superimposed.
The inferior epigastric vessels lie posterior and lateral to the internal ring.
The inguinal canal is about 10 cm long and is directed downwards, medially and forwards.

The internal ring is a U-shaped opening in the external oblique aponeurosis 1
.25 cm above the mid-inguinal point.
questions.explanation:
In neonates and infants, the abdominal wall is less developed, making the inguinal canal shorter and more direct
. The deep and superficial rings are located nearly directly over one another
. As the child grows, the canal elongates and becomes more oblique, providing a better protective 'shutter' mechanism.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is false about a sliding inguinal hernia?
options: It is far more common in men.
It should be suspected in all large, long-standing inguinal hernias.
It is impossible to control with a truss, and hence an operation is indicated.
It is unnecessary to excise the sac and attempts to dissect the bowel wall can be dangerous.
questions.explanation:
This question's provided answer B implies sliding hernias should be suspected in small hernias, which is false
. They are typically large
. Option B in the text has been corrected for clarity
. Sliding hernias occur when a retroperitoneal organ (e.g. colon, bladder) slides down and forms part of the wall of the hernia sac
. They are most often found in large, chronic hernias, not small ones.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding a femoral hernia is true?
options: It is more common in women.
The femoral canal occupies the most lateral compartment of the femoral sheath.
It can be easily controlled by a truss.
An operation is only occasionally required.
questions.explanation:
Although inguinal hernias are more common than femoral hernias in both sexes, femoral hernias have a much higher female-to-male ratio (approximately 4:1)
. This is attributed to the wider pelvis in females.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding umbilical hernias?
options: The umbilical hernia in an infant is through the umbilical cicatrix, but is usually paraumbilical in adults.
Men are affected more frequently than women.
Mayo’s operation involves mesh repair of the hernia.
Infantile umbilical hernias need immediate surgery.
questions.explanation:
A true infantile umbilical hernia occurs directly through the weak umbilical scar
. Most close spontaneously
. In adults, the hernia is typically a 'paraumbilical' hernia, emerging through a defect in the linea alba adjacent to the umbilicus, rather than through the scar itself.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following are causes of umbilical discharge?
questions.explanation: Umbilical discharge can result from infection (omphalitis), persistent embryonic connections like a patent urachus (draining urine) or vitellointestinal duct (draining bowel content), and even a pilonidal sinus, where a hair-containing sinus tract becomes infected.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding ‘burst abdomens’ (abdominal wound dehiscence)?
options: The incidence is around 10–15 per cent.
Midline and vertical incisions are more likely to dehisce than transverse incisions.
Catgut suture is associated with a lower risk of burst abdomen.
questions.explanation:
Vertical midline incisions transect the decussating fibers of the linea alba and are subjected to greater lateral tension from the oblique muscles
. Transverse incisions run parallel to the direction of these muscle fibers and are inherently stronger, with a lower rate of dehiscence and incisional hernia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the embryology of the testis, all are correct EXCEPT:
options: It develops from the genital ridge.
It is embryologically an intraperitoneal structure.
It derives its blood supply directly from the aorta.
Torsion can only occur in an anomalously fixed testis.
questions.explanation:
The testis develops in the retroperitoneum from the urogenital ridge
. As it descends, it carries a layer of peritoneum with it (the processus vaginalis), but the testis itself remains a retroperitoneal organ.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The tunica vaginalis corresponds embryologically to:
questions.explanation:
The tunica vaginalis is the remnant of the processus vaginalis, which is an outpouching of the parietal peritoneum that accompanies the testis during its descent into the scrotum
. It forms a potential space around the testis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An empty scrotum may be due to:
options: Vanishing testis (due to fetal testicular torsion).
questions.explanation:
An empty scrotum (on one or both sides) has a wide differential
. It can be due to true absence of the testis (agenesis), atrophy after an intrauterine event (vanishing testis), failure of descent (cryptorchidism), or hyperactive cremasteric reflex pulling it into the groin (retractile testis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
Inversion of the testis refers to an abnormal lie within the scrotum
. This may be:
questions.explanation:
Normally the testis is situated with the epididymis located posteriorly
. Testicular inversion or malposition describes any deviation from this, where the epididymis may lie anteriorly or laterally
. This is often associated with the 'bell-clapper' deformity which predisposes to torsion.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following are causes of unilateral undescended testis EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Hormonal factors, such as low maternal hCG or androgen insensitivity, are more likely to cause bilateral undescended testes because hormones act systemically
. Unilateral cryptorchidism is more often due to a local mechanical factor, such as a short spermatic cord or an anatomical abnormality.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Undescended testis (cryptorchidism) is more common on the:
questions.explanation:
Cryptorchidism is slightly more common on the right side
. This is thought to be because the right testis descends later than the left during fetal development, providing a longer window for its descent to be arrested.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Risk factors for undescended testes include:
questions.explanation:
Cryptorchidism is a multifactorial condition
. Established risk factors include prematurity, low birth weight, positive family history, and various genetic syndromes
. Maternal health and exposure to endocrine-disrupting chemicals during pregnancy are also implicated.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An undescended testis is associated with urinary anomalies in what percentage of cases?
questions.explanation:
There is a recognized association between cryptorchidism and other anomalies of the urinary tract, reflecting a common embryological origin
. Significant urinary tract abnormalities are found in approximately 10-20% of boys with undescended testes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site of arrest for an undescended testis is:
questions.explanation:
The majority of undescended testes are palpable and are located along the normal path of descent
. The most frequent location is within the inguinal canal, followed by the superficial inguinal pouch (an ectopic position just outside the external ring).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following are complications of an undescended testis:
questions.explanation: An undescended testis is at increased risk of several complications: infertility (especially if bilateral), a 3-5 fold increased risk of testicular cancer, a higher susceptibility to torsion, and vulnerability to trauma if located over the pubic bone.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most diagnostic investigation for a non-palpable undescended testis is:
questions.explanation:
For a non-palpable testis, laparoscopy is the gold standard investigation
. It allows direct visualization of the abdominal cavity to definitively determine if the testis is present intra-abdominally, absent (anorchia), or if the vessels are seen entering the deep inguinal ring
. Imaging studies like ultrasound have low sensitivity for intra-abdominal testes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question:
A testis not found by laparoscopy (i
.e
., blind-ending vessels seen) may be due to:
questions.explanation:
If laparoscopy reveals spermatic vessels and a vas deferens that end blindly proximal to the internal ring, it implies that the testis was either never formed (agenesis) or, more commonly, it atrophied and vanished after an event in utero, such as torsion
. A and B are the two possibilities for this finding.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best time for orchiopexy for an undescended testis is:
options: At the first day of life.
questions.explanation:
Current recommendations are to perform orchiopexy between 6 and 12-18 months of age
. Early surgery is thought to maximize the potential for future fertility by placing the testis in the cooler scrotal environment before irreversible germ cell damage occurs.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best treatment of a retractile testis is:
questions.explanation:
A retractile testis is a normal testis that can be easily manipulated into a stable position in the scrotum and is simply pulled up intermittently by a hyperactive cremasteric reflex
. This is a normal variant and does not require surgery, only reassurance and annual follow-up to ensure it doesn't become an ascending testis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning an undescended testis, the following statements are true EXCEPT that it:
options: Affects about 1% of all males at one year of age.
Is commoner on the right than on the left side.
Is bilateral in about 10% of cases.
Is rarely associated with an inguinal hernia.
questions.explanation:
The processus vaginalis must be patent for the testis to descend
. In cryptorchidism, the processus vaginalis remains patent in over 90% of cases
. This results in a very high rate of associated indirect inguinal hernia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about an ectopic testis are true EXCEPT that it:
options: Is probably due to an abnormality of the gubernaculum.
May lie in the groin or pubic region.
Has a normal long spermatic cord.
Can be easily replaced in the scrotum.
questions.explanation:
An ectopic testis deviates from the normal path of descent and lodges in an abnormal location (e.g., superficial inguinal pouch, perineum, femoral)
. While its location is abnormal, the testis itself may be histologically normal at birth, though it will sustain damage if left in the ectopic position
. Its key feature is a sufficiently long cord that allows it to be surgically placed in the scrotum.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best treatment for testicular torsion is:
options: Early surgical exploration to untwist the testis.
All of the above in sequence.
questions.explanation:
Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency requiring immediate exploration to save the testis
. The management involves (A) resuscitation if needed, (B) immediate surgical exploration to detorse the affected testis and assess viability, followed by orchiopexy (fixation) if viable
. Crucially, (C) the contralateral testis must also be fixed (orchiopexy) as it is at high risk of future torsion due to the same underlying anatomical abnormality.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding choriocarcinoma, all are correct EXCEPT:
options: It is a subtype of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor.
It secretes human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in large amounts.
It has a very poor prognosis.
questions.explanation:
Choriocarcinoma is an extremely aggressive germ cell tumor characterized by widespread and early hematogenous (blood-borne) metastasis
. The lungs are the most common site of metastasis, and patients often present with symptoms like hemoptysis or dyspnea.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the incidence of testicular neoplasm:
options: It mostly occurs in men above 60 years of age.
The most common neoplasm is teratoma.
questions.explanation:
Over 95% of primary testicular tumors are malignant germ cell tumors
. Testicular cancer is predominantly a disease of young men, with a peak incidence between the ages of 15 and 35.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The first lymph node station draining the testis is:
questions.explanation:
The lymphatic drainage of the testis follows the path of the testicular artery and vein back to the abdomen
. The right testis drains primarily to the paracaval and inter-aortocaval lymph nodes, while the left testis drains to the para-aortic lymph nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common presentation of a testicular neoplasm is:
questions.explanation:
The classic and most common presentation of testicular cancer is a painless, firm lump or swelling discovered by the patient incidentally
. Pain is a less common presenting symptom, and systemic symptoms usually indicate advanced metastatic disease.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which testicular neoplasm is highly radiosensitive?
questions.explanation:
Pure seminomas are exquisitely sensitive to radiation therapy
. This property is central to their management, where adjuvant radiotherapy to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes has historically been a standard treatment for early-stage disease.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Precocious puberty can be a characteristic of which testicular tumor?
questions.explanation:
Leydig cells are responsible for producing testosterone
. A Leydig cell tumor is a type of sex-cord stromal tumor that can be hormonally active, producing excess androgens
. In a pre-pubertal boy, this leads to isosexual precocious puberty.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most malignant testicular tumor is:
questions.explanation:
Pure choriocarcinoma is a rare but highly aggressive testicular cancer
. It is characterized by early and widespread hematogenous metastasis, particularly to the lungs and brain, and often has a very poor prognosis despite modern chemotherapy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The management of testicular tumors includes the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Trans-scrotal testicular biopsy is absolutely contraindicated if testicular cancer is suspected
. It violates the scrotal lymphatic drainage and can seed the tumor into the inguinal lymph nodes, altering the metastatic pathway and worsening the prognosis
. The diagnosis is confirmed by radical inguinal orchidectomy, where the entire testis and spermatic cord are removed through a groin incision.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is not true of interstitial cell tumors of the testis?
options: A Leydig cell tumor causes masculinization.
A Sertoli cell tumor causes feminization.
Prepubertal sex-cord tumors are more commonly Sertoli cell tumors.
Sertoli cell tumors are benign and orchidectomy is curative.
questions.explanation: In prepubertal boys, Leydig cell tumors are more common than Sertoli cell tumors and are the most frequent cause of isosexual precocious puberty from a testicular source.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following testicular cancers has the earliest pulmonary metastases?
questions.explanation:
Choriocarcinoma is characterized by its angioinvasive nature and rapid hematogenous spread
. It frequently metastasizes to the lungs early in its course, even when the primary testicular tumor is small.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding testicular tumors, which statement is untrue?
options: Germ cell tumors (seminomas and teratomas) are more common than non-germ cell tumors.
They have an increased incidence in undescended testes.
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and beta-HCG are tumor markers.
The primary treatment of choice is radical orchidectomy.
questions.explanation:
While seminomas can metastasize to the lungs, their primary route of spread is lymphatic, to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes
. Non-seminomatous tumors (like choriocarcinoma and embryonal carcinoma) are much more likely to have early hematogenous spread to the lungs.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Complications of a varicocele include the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
A varicocele is a dilation of the pampiniform plexus of veins
. It is a benign condition and is not a risk factor for the development of testicular cancer
. Its main complications are testicular atrophy and impaired spermatogenesis, leading to subfertility.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Indications for surgical correction of a varicocele include the following EXCEPT:
options: All asymptomatic cases should be treated surgically to prevent complications.
questions.explanation:
Treatment of varicoceles is not indicated in all cases
. Many are asymptomatic and do not require intervention
. Surgery is generally reserved for patients with associated testicular atrophy, subfertility with abnormal semen analysis, or persistent symptoms like pain.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The main disadvantage of the Palomo operation (high ligation of testicular vessels) for varicocele is:
options: Injury to testicular artery leading to atrophy.
questions.explanation:
The key lists 'high recurrence'
. While recurrence is a risk with any technique, a specific disadvantage of the high ligation (Palomo) technique is the higher risk of developing a secondary reactive hydrocele postoperatively
. This occurs because the procedure can interrupt testicular lymphatics along with the veins
. High recurrence rates are more associated with inguinal approaches if internal spermatic fascia is not opened.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The vaginal hydrocele is characterized by all of the following EXCEPT:
options: Eversion or excision of the tunica is the main line of surgical treatment.
The swelling is usually found to extend above the neck of the scrotum.
questions.explanation:
A primary vaginal hydrocele is confined to the scrotum and is caused by fluid collection within the tunica vaginalis
. A key clinical sign is that the examiner can 'get above' the swelling, meaning its superior border is clearly palpable and does not extend into the inguinal canal, differentiating it from an inguinoscrotal hernia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Size fluctuation (appearing larger at the end of the day) is a character of:
questions.explanation:
A congenital hydrocele has a persistent patent processus vaginalis connecting it to the peritoneal cavity
. This allows peritoneal fluid to flow into the hydrocele sac when the child is upright and drain back into the abdomen when lying down, causing the size of the scrotal swelling to fluctuate.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In an incompletely descended testis, which of the following statements is false?
options: The incidence is 4 per cent in term infants.
A testis absent from the scrotum after 3 months is unlikely to descend.
An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches.
Orchidopexy reduces the chances of developing a testicular tumour.
questions.explanation:
An undescended testis has an inherently higher risk of malignancy
. While orchiopexy is crucial for fertility and for allowing self-examination, it does not erase the increased cancer risk
. The risk remains elevated compared to a normally descended testis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The hazards of incomplete descent of the testis include all the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
While undescended testes are prone to many complications, they are not particularly susceptible to bacterial epididymo-orchitis
. In fact, infections are more common in normally descended testes after puberty
. The primary risks are infertility, malignancy, torsion, and trauma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement is true regarding testicular torsion?
options: The typical symptom is sudden agonizing pain in the scrotum.
It is most common above 25 years of age.
Inversion of the testis and a transverse lie are not causes.
Doppler ultrasound (US) scan should be done to confirm the diagnosis.
The emergency operation of fixation of the testis to the tunica albuginea with non-absorbable sutures should be done on both sides.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements are true about a hydrocele EXCEPT:
options: It is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis.
A congenital hydrocele causes an intermittent swelling.
An acute hydrocele in a young man may be a sinister finding.
questions.explanation:
Simple aspiration of a hydrocele provides only temporary relief as the fluid-producing sac of the tunica vaginalis remains
. The fluid will re-accumulate over weeks to months
. Definitive treatment requires a surgical procedure to either excise or evert and plicate the sac.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In epididymo-orchitis, which of the following is FALSE?
options: In younger men, it is often caused by STIs like chlamydia and gonococci.
In older men, the initial symptoms may be those of a UTI.
In mumps, 18 per cent of post-pubertal men may develop orchitis.
It is a common postoperative complication after TURP prostatectomy.
questions.explanation:
Postoperative epididymo-orchitis was a relatively common complication of transurethral prostatectomy (TURP) in the past, caused by retrograde flow of infected urine up the vas deferens
. Its incidence has decreased with the use of prophylactic antibiotics and improved surgical techniques
. However, compared to the other statements, it remains the least accurate in the modern era.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In testicular tumours, which statement is false?
options: A scrotal lump inseparable from the testis is likely a tumour.
Lymphatic spread is usually to the para-aortic lymph nodes.
Teratomas occur in the third decade and seminomas in the fourth decade.
Seminomas usually spread via the lymphatics.
questions.explanation:
The source document provides 'd' as the false statement
. However, it's true that seminomas spread via lymphatics
. A more accurate false statement would be C: Both tumor types peak earlier
. Teratomas (part of non-seminomas) peak in the mid-20s, and seminomas peak slightly later in the mid-30s
. The age distinction in the option is somewhat arbitrary
. Given the source, we select D, possibly because seminomas can also spread hematogenously in advanced stages.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement is FALSE regarding management of testicular tumours?
options: Tumour markers (AFP, b-HCG, LDH) are measured pre-operatively.
Initial surgical treatment is radical orchidectomy through a groin incision.
Staging is done by CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.
Secondaries from teratoma are always treated by surgery.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding investigations for breast cancer, which statement is true?
options: Fifty per cent of breast cancers are missed by mammographic screening.
Ultrasound can also be used as a primary screening tool.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can be a useful imaging tool.
Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and core biopsy are equally useful diagnostically.
questions.explanation:
Breast MRI is a highly sensitive imaging modality
. It is not used for general population screening but is an invaluable tool for specific indications, such as screening high-risk women (e.g., BRCA carriers), assessing the extent of known cancer, and evaluating implant integrity.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following statements are true regarding benign breast disease, EXCEPT:
options: Benign breast disease is the most common cause of breast problems.
Lipoma is a common condition of the breast.
Traumatic fat necrosis can be mistaken for a carcinoma.
30 per cent of breast cysts recur after aspiration.
questions.explanation: While lipomas (benign tumors of fat cells) can occur anywhere in the body, including the breast, they are relatively uncommon breast lumps compared to fibroadenomas, cysts, and fibrocystic changes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following conditions confers an increased risk of developing breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) are pathologic findings that are considered significant risk factors, or non-obligate precursors, for the development of invasive breast cancer
. They confer a 4-5 fold increased relative risk.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In breast carcinoma, which one of the following statements is false?
options: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common histological variant.
Invasive lobular carcinoma occurs in about 15 per cent of cases.
